channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Anger Overflows in Nigeria as Economy Dives
item.media:description: A neighborhood in Lagos, Nigeria, during one of its frequent power failures.
item.media:credit: Ashley Gilbertson for The New York Times
item.description: Plummeting oil prices have set off an economic unraveling and collective anger in a country that is among the world’s top oil producers.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY

item.title: Brazilian Speaker, in About-Face, Won’t Annul Rousseff’s Impeachment
item.media:description: Waldir Maranhão, speaker of the lower house of Brazil’s Congress, in Brasilia, on Monday. Mr. Maranhão annulled the impeachment vote and then backtracked on his decision in less than 24 hours.
item.description: The sudden twist by the speaker of the lower house comes as the upper house is scheduled to start voting on whether to remove her from office.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO

item.title: Judge in Mexico Says El Chapo Can Be Extradited to U.S.
item.media:description: Soldiers in Mexico transporting Joaquín Guzmán Loera, known as El Chapo, back to prison in January.
item.description: The ruling puts the drug kingpin Joaquín Guzmán Loera, who has escaped from Mexican prisons twice, one step closer to prison in the United States.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED and PAULINA VILLEGAS

item.title: Monterchi Journal: Italians Agree Fresco Is a Masterpiece, but All Else Is Up for Debate
item.media:description: The Madonna del Parto by Piero della Francesca is currently displayed at a schoolhouse that has been turned into a museum in Monterchi, Italy. The fresco is the subject of a wide dispute.
item.media:credit: Uriel Sinai for The New York Times
item.description: For decades, there has been a dispute over how and where Piero della Francesca’s Madonna del Parto should be displayed, and even who owns it.
item.dc:creator: JIM YARDLEY
item.category: Ministry of Cultural Heritage and Tourism (Italy)

item.title: Sadiq Khan, London’s Mayor, Hits Back at Donald Trump’s Comments on Islam
item.media:description: Sadiq Khan, the newly elected mayor of London, spoke to supporters on his first day, at City Hall in London on Monday.
item.description: The new mayor said on Twitter that the Republican candidate’s “ignorant view of Islam could make both our countries less safe.”
item.dc:creator: LIAM STACK

item.title: As War Strangles Yemen, Many Fear the Grip Will Never Break
item.media:description: Fighters during clashes with Houthi rebels and their allies in March in Taiz, Yemen.
item.description: A frenzied escalation of violence over the last few days is threatening a cease-fire that was supposed to build confidence for peace talks.
item.dc:creator: KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: Egypt to Pay Families of 3 Mexican Tourists Killed by Military
item.description: They will receive $140,000 each, but officials admitted no guilt in the episode in which helicopters mistakenly fired on a group of picnickers, killing 12 in all.
item.dc:creator: NOUR YOUSSEF

item.title: Son of Pakistani Ex-Prime Minister, Kidnapped in 2013, Is Rescued
item.media:description: Ali Haider Gilani, a son of former Prime Minister Yousaf Raza Gilani of Pakistan, in 2013 before he was kidnapped.
item.description: Ali Haider Gilani was freed by Afghan and United States security forces during a raid on Qaeda militants in Afghanistan, officials said.
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD and MUJIB MASHAL

item.title: Obama to Be First Sitting President to Visit Hiroshima
item.media:description: President Obama last week. A visit to Hiroshima was hotly debated within the White House for months as Mr. Obama planned his trip to Vietnam and Japan.
item.description: The visit carries weighty symbolism for the president, who does not want to be seen as apologizing for America’s use of atomic bombs to help end World War II.
item.dc:creator: JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS and JONATHAN SOBLE

item.title: Turkish Border Guards Accused of Attacking Syrian Refugees
item.media:description: Refugees near the northern city of Azaz, Syria, waiting to cross into Turkey in February. A Turkish government spokesman said on Tuesday that Turkey’s open-door policy did not amount to open borders.
item.description: Human Rights Watch says the guards killed five refugees and wounded 14 others as they tried to cross the border. Turkey denied the accusation.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU and KARAM SHOUMALI
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Sinosphere: Chinese Panel Rules Against Plaintiff in Transgender Job Discrimination Case
item.media:description: Mr. C holding the ruling by an arbitration panel that rejected his demand for a month’s pay and a written apology for what he said was discrimination because he is transgender.
item.description: The panel rejected the demand by the plaintiff, identified as Mr. C., for an additional month’s pay and an apology.
item.dc:creator: VANESSA PIAO

item.title: U.S. Sails Warship Near Island in South China Sea, Challenging Chinese Claims
item.media:description: The William P. Lawrence, a guided missile destroyer, in Coronado, Calif., in January. The ship ventured into the vicinity of Fiery Cross Reef, an artificial island that China constructed in the South China Sea, on Tuesday.
item.description: The operation was intended to show that the United States opposes China’s efforts to restrict navigation in the strategic waterway, the Pentagon said.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: North Korean General, Thought to Be Executed, Resurfaces
item.media:description: The leader of North Korea, Kim Jong-un, right, with soldiers who took part in the military parade in October 2015.
item.media:credit: Korean Central News Agency, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Ri Yong-gil, who was said to have been executed in February on corruption charges, is not only alive but has been newly selected for senior posts, according to state media reports.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Knife Attacker Stabs 4, Killing One, Near Munich
item.description: The assailant, 27, had no police record and had exhibited symptoms of mental illness, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY

item.title: Sinosphere: Q. and A.: Jeremy Brown on the Cultural Revolution at the Grass Roots
item.media:description: Red Guards parading through the snow in Beijing on Feb. 10, 1967.
item.description: The historian says a focus on elite politics and intellectuals ignores the actual experience of the mass of ordinary Chinese during that tumultuous decade.
item.dc:creator: IAN JOHNSON

item.title: Airstrike Kills a Top ISIS Commander in Iraq, Pentagon Says
item.description: A spokesman said Abu Wahib and three other Islamic State members had been killed in a coalition attack in Anbar Province.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: In Fort McMurray, Fire Leaves a Black Line of Destruction
item.description: A school intact on one side of a street, a home devastated on the other. In Fort McMurray, Alberta, where a fire continued Monday, contrasts abound.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Rodrigo Duterte Brings Familiar Tone to Philippine Election
item.media:description: Rodrigo Duterte, the front-runner in the Philippine presidential election, cast his vote at a school on Monday in Davao City, on the southern island of Mindanao.
item.description: Likened to American candidate Donald J. Trump, the front-runner to be the archipelago’s next president has drawn criticism for his words against women, and against Pope Francis.
item.dc:creator: FLOYD WHALEY and ADEEL HASSAN

item.title: Brazil Reels Again as Impeachment Vote Is Declared Invalid
item.media:description: Waldir Maranhão, the new speaker of Brazil’s lower house of Congress, on Monday annulled the vote to impeach Ms. Rouseff, contending that procedural rules had been broken.
item.media:credit: Antonio Augusto/Agencia Camara, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.description: Politicians scrambled to determine how the decision by the new speaker of Brazil’s lower house of Congress might affect President Dilma Rousseff’s fate.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO

item.title: BBC Faces Turning Point in Mission as Pressures Bear Down
item.media:description: The London headquarters of the British Broadcasting Corporation. Its directors have implemented a series of staff cuts and reorganizations intended to address its array of challenges.
item.description: As Britain’s government prepares a new BBC charter, the country is questioning what role the broadcaster should have in the digital age.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Putin Swipes at West During Victory Day Parade in Moscow
item.media:description: Russian jet fighters flew over Red Square during the Victory Day military parade in Moscow on Monday.
item.description: At the annual celebration of victory over Nazi Germany, the Russian president seemed to criticize the United States over its actions in Syria.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS

item.title: India’s Answer to Sex Attacks? Panic Buttons and GPS on All Phones
item.media:description: Police officers near a house where a 15-year-old girl was set on fire after being raped in Tigri, India, in March.
item.description: The policy change would require new phones to allow users to press a number that alerts the police and loved ones in an emergency.
item.dc:creator: KATIE ROGERS

item.title: Austrian Chancellor, Werner Faymann, Resigns as Right Wing Rises
item.description: The resignation of Mr. Faymann threw the country into deeper uncertainty amid a rightward political shift fueled by anxiety over migration.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE

item.title: Sinosphere: After Maoist Music and Slogan, Harsh Light Shines on Chinese Show
item.media:description: A military honor guard outside the Great Hall of the People in Beijing, where a performance of Maoist music was staged on May 2.
item.description: The performance ignited accusations that officials connived in rekindling Cultural Revolution-era veneration of Mao right before the 50th anniversary of the start of that traumatic era.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: What in the World: The Wrong Day to Be a Cat in Belgium
item.media:credit: Illustration by Cari Vander Yacht; Photo by Inna Astakhova / shutterstock.com
item.description: The people of Ypres, Belgium, once dealt with feral cats by throwing them off a bell tower. Today, they host a cat-themed celebration instead.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK J. LYONS

item.title: What in the World: Look Out, Celebrity Chefs. Here Comes Kim Jong-un.
item.media:credit: Illustration by Antonio de Luca; Photo by KCNA, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Entities linked to North Korea run an expanding empire of restaurants abroad, pumping badly needed profits back to the North.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK J. LYONS

item.title: What in the World: 25 Seconds That Could Save a Firefighter’s Life (or Not)
item.media:description: Government-issue fire shelters.
item.description: A fire shelter is mandatory equipment when fighting a wildfire in the United States, but in Canada, firefighters stopped carrying them in 2005.
item.dc:creator: FERNANDA SANTOS

item.title: What in the World: Rents in London? If You Have to Ask ...
item.media:credit: Illustration by Tamara Shopsin, Photo by nok nok/shutterstock.com
item.description: An average apartment in London now costs nine-tenths of an average worker’s pay.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Rodrigo Duterte’s Rivals Concede in Philippine Election
item.media:description: Rodrigo Duterte posing with a supporter on Monday after voting in his hometown of Davao, in the southern Philippines.
item.description: Mr. Duterte, the mayor of Davao City, appeared to have an unbeatable lead in the presidential race.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD C. PADDOCK and FLOYD WHALEY

item.title: David Cameron, Urging Against ‘Brexit,’ Focuses on Security
item.media:description: Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain, right, and David Miliband, a former foreign secretary, before a speech on the European Union at the British Museum in central London on Monday.
item.description: By centering on more than just economics, the prime minister’s argument brought his campaign to persuade his country to remain in the E.U. into a new phase.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: On Europe Day, Is There Anything to Celebrate?
item.media:description: Britons will decide on June 23 whether to leave the 28-nation European Union.
item.description: The holiday marks a 1950 speech laying out the case for what became the European Union, but the bloc faces greater challenges than ever.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Putin and the Night Wolves vs. Poland
item.media:description: Members of the Night Wolves left the Mount of Glory monument on the outskirts of Minsk, Belarus, during their rally from Moscow to Berlin.
item.description: Now a motorcycle club is shaping Russia’s foreign policy.
item.dc:creator: MASHA GESSEN

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Chappatte on the Philippine Election
item.description: With more than 92 percent of the votes counted Tuesday, Rodrigo Duterte appeared to have an unbeatable lead in the presidential race.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK CHAPPATTE

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Sadiq Khan vs. Donald Trump
item.media:description: Sadiq Khan, center, walking to City Hall in London, on his first day as mayor.
item.media:credit: Jonathan Brady/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.description: The new mayor of London is a Muslim. Trump would bar him from the United States.
item.dc:creator: ROGER COHEN

item.title: Alissa Rubin, 2016 Pulitzer Winner, Reports From the Front Lines
item.media:description: Alissa Rubin
item.description: Ms. Rubin has spent much of her career covering Iraq, Afghanistan and the Balkans.
item.dc:creator: MIKE McPHATE

item.title: Lens Blog: Photography Pulitzer for Coverage of Refugee Crisis
item.description: The New York Times and Thomson Reuters shared the Pulitzer Prize for breaking news photography for coverage of Europe’s refugee crisis. Jessica Rinaldi of the Boston Globe won the feature photography prize for her story of a boy who endured abuse at the hands of those he trusted.
item.dc:creator: DAVID GONZALEZ and JAMES ESTRIN

item.title: On the Ground in Aleppo: Bloodshed, Misery and Hope
item.media:description: A civilian evacuated a baby on Friday from a site that had been hit by airstrikes in a rebel-controlled area of Aleppo, Syria. Inhabitants of the city carry on with work and school despite fighting that has killed more than 200 civilians in the past week.
item.description: The New York Times’s Cairo bureau chief reported from Aleppo, Syria, where inhabitants try to carry on despite a civil war’s inescapable reality.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: How ISIS Built the Machinery of Terror Under Europe’s Gaze
item.media:description: The Paris attacks left 130 dead in November, but a branch within the Islamic State was obsessed with striking Europe at least two years before then.
item.description: Two years before the Paris and Brussels assaults, a special branch of the group was churning out smaller attacks that the authorities repeatedly discounted as isolated or random acts.
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
